sentence:
You can use the following instruction:

new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList(array));
Element[] array = new Element[] { new Element(1)  new Element(2)  new Element(3) };
The list returned from asList has fixed size.
So if you want to be able to add or remove elements from the returned list in your code you ll need to wrap it in a new ArrayList.
The list returned from asList() is backed by the original array.
If you modify the original array  the list will be modified as well.

(old thread but just 2 cents as none mention Guava or other libs and some other details)

If You Can Use Guava

It s worth pointing out the Guava way which greatly simplifies these shenanigans:

Usage

For an Immutable List
Use the ImmutableList class and its of() and copyOf()
